thread.title: Plan your week’s theatre: top tickets | Stage | The Guardian
thread.title_full: Plan your week’s theatre: top tickets | Stage | The Guardian

author: Lyn Gardner
title: Plan your week’s theatre: top tickets | Stage | The Guardian
text:
Monday 20 February 2017 07.00 GMT Last modified on Monday 20 February 2017 07.03 GMT Monday 
Sinners Club, at the Other Room, Cardiff , is atmospheric and clever gig-theatre that stays in the mind. At the Green Rooms Hotel, Wood Green, Loose Tongue’s site-specific sound installation, Hotel Europe, considers borders and citizenship. Tuesday 
Breach Theatre’s Tank – about experiments trying to teach dolphins to talk English – cleverly dissects power, patriarchy and language. It’s at the Drum, Plymouth , from tonight. People Show’s latest, The Last Straw, opens at Oval House , London, and like all the company’s shows it will be a complete surprise – as much to those who have made it as the audience. Sh!t Theatre’s Letters to Windsor House, looking at what the rental housing crisis does to personal relationships, is at the New Wolsey, Ipswich , and on tour. Homecomings, a festival of new plays by prisoners and ex-prisoners, opens tonight at Theatre 503, London. Wednesday 
The spirit of Glasgow’s much-missed Arches theatre lives on in Take Me Somewhere, a citywide festival programmed by the National Theatre of Scotland’s incoming artistic director, Jackie Wylie . It opens with Kieran Hurley’s Heads Up at the Tron . There’s more theatre with music at the Tristan Bates theatre, Covent Garden, where Marie Corelli’s Faustian novel, The Sorrows of Satan, is transposed to the stage. Imelda Staunton and Conleth Hill star in Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf? at the Harold Pinter theatre, London, from tonight. Madame Bovary is relocated to a trading estate plumbing company in Bea Roberts’ clever Infinity Pool, a play with no actors, which is at the North Wall , Oxford, from tonight. Philip Ridley’s Killer, directed by Jamie Lloyd, plays in rep with the former’s excellent The Pitchfork Disney at Shoreditch town hall. The untold stories of Jamaican soldiers in the first world war is told in Patricia Crumper’s Chigger Foot Boys at Tara theatre, London. Thursday 
Marius von Mayenburg’s Plastic, a satirical look at middle-class pretensions, has its UK premiere in a production by Matthew Dunster at the Ustinov, Bath. Young people in care are the subject of Paddy Campbell’s Leaving, produced by Curious Monkey at Northern Stage, Newcastle . The circus duet, Cul de Sac, explores the best and worst of human relationships at Jackson’s Lane tonight and tomorrow. David Rudkin’s rarely performed Ashes is revived by David Thacker at the Octagon, Bolton. The Chinese fable-inspired Snow in Midsummer opens at the RSC, Stratford. The brilliant Lucy Ellinson is a US fighter pilot who now operates remote-controlled drones in the superb Grounded, which returns to the Gate, Notting Hill. Friday and the weekend 
Jack Thorne teams up with composer Stephen Warbeck for the musical Junkyard, at Bristol Old Vic. The Cut festival , at various venues in east London, explores the history and social relevance of the barber shop. Richard Bean’s The Hypocrite, about Hull during the English civil war, opens at Hull Truck . The ever lovely Little Bulbbring Wail, a cabaret about why humans and whales sing, to Salisbury playhouse. Rosencrantz and Guilderstern, with Daniel Radcliffe, Joshua McGuire and David Haig, opens at the Old Vic , London. Melly Still and April de Angelis collaborate on Elena Ferrante’s My Brilliant Friend at the Rose, Kingston. If you are free on Sunday afternoon, there is a great lineup of talent at the Theatre Royal Haymarket , including Mel Giedroyc and Denise Gough in Moving Stories , a fundraiser for the UN refugee agency featuring work from Richard Bean, David Edgar, Phil Porter and others. Back to Ours brings some fantastic shows, including Mark Thomas’s The Red Shed and Hijinx theatre’s Meet Fred, to local neighbourhoods in Hull as part of Hull city of culture.
